H0.text: More carbon dioxide will be trapped in the unplanted field as a result of the greater precipitation the farmer received during the year he chose not to plant crops there.

H1.text: Erosion of topsoil will increase in the field when, for one year, a farmer chooses not to plant crops in it and receives greater precipitation than normal.

H2.text: Invasive species will inhabit the field that the farmer left unplanted during a year of greater-than‑normal precipitation.

H3.text: Animals will dig burrows in the field is the most likely occurrence in an unplanted field that received greater-than‑normal precipitation, after the farmer decided not to plant crops there that year.

A4.text: The relationship is particularly strong if heavy rainfall occurs at times when, or in locations where, the soil's surface is not well protected by vegetation.

A5.text: Wet, saturated soils will not be able to absorb as much rainwater, leading to higher levels of surface runoff and thus higher erosivity for a given volume of rainfall.
